title: Nausea and Contingency
description: A quick, practical guide to Nausea and Contingency.

hook.text: In Sartre's novel Nausea, a man stares at a tree root and is overwhelmed by its pointless existence.

buildup.text: He realizes nothing has to exist. The root, the bench, himself â€” all could just as easily not be.

discovery.text: This is contingency: the world exists without reason or necessity. There's no 'why' behind it.

twist.text: The feeling isn't intellectual. It's physical â€” a nausea that comes from seeing reality stripped bare.

climax.text: Sartre used fiction to convey what arguments can't: the raw, visceral shock of existence.

punchline.text: Existence is absurd. Nausea is the proof.

quiz.question: What does 'contingency' mean in existential philosophy?
options: Nothing has to exist; existence has no necessary reason
